instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.PP3V3R3V0_AON: What is PP3V3R3V0_AON? PP3V3R3V0_AON is the first power rail you need to get a USB-C charger to go from 5v to 20v on an A1534 Macbook with an 820-00045 board..
definitions.5V_S4: What is 5V_S4? This is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S4” – when you see this, assume the person typing it meant to type “PP5V_S4”.
definitions.3V3_S4: What is 3V3_S4? This is an abbreviation of PP3V3_S4, a 3.3v power rail when the machine is in an S4 state. .
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead CPU?
threads.message:
No History and NO no sign of Water Damage

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>:  8.59V
<SIGNAL>PPVBUS_E85</SIGNAL>:  14.4V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>: 14.35V as I can also see it on the USB C Tester with the display ( I have 14.8V but Not pulling Current, 0A )
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.302V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL>: 3.229V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.296
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3H_LDO</SIGNAL>: 4.996V
[B]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>: 5.016V[/B]

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 3.302V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>: 3.302V
[B]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>:  0V[/B]

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>: 0V     

<SIGNAL>PCH_RTCRST_L</SIGNAL>:  3.290V
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL>:  3.0293V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>: 3.026V
[B]<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL>: 0V[/B]   <RESISTOR>R1302</RESISTOR>: 336 KOhms  OK

triggered  <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and checked <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>  not pulsing


I've had <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> both present after taking out the board out the chassis ( disconnected from battery ),    and mesured the next rails ( S0 all not OK ).
After what I've unplugged the charger and replugged since then back to no <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> .

I've seen another member having this same issue, but he never answer

Now I have all S0 state rails but the board is getting very hot around <CHIP>U0500</CHIP> and of course no sign of life ( no boing sound when plugging charger, no display etc....)
My guess is that this board is part of the many which have Dead CPU......
I'm wondering how is it possible to pay a such expensive price for hardware having this kind of failure after only 2 years old?
That me think that Apple is doing that on purpose  just to sell more  garbage around the world for gold price. Why people don't do class action for this case.

I'm tempted to reflow the CPU just like that for fun .....after all

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead CPU?
threads.message:
You mix the information and is dificil to follow you.
Mentioned missing <SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> present and missing <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL>..
Then S0 voltages present too.
Which is the actual state of your board???

However I don not recommend you to waste time on it.
All these boards end with dead CPU.
Apple didn't put a fan for some reason; machine will not last too much after warranty ends.
If you really have time to spend, try to reflow entire board on IR oven.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead CPU?
threads.message:
Again Thank you for your answer.....
First I've noticed that I didn't had the <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL> but <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> was OK: This was with the board having the battery connected
Withoiut battery it goes to S0 state with CPU heating.....
I've also tried to connect those USB C adapter with normal usb to see if an optical mouse lights ON: No Light

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead CPU?
threads.message:
Hi 2Informaticos,
I've noticed that the PRam aera was corrupted when I read it whith the Medusa,so I've wrote a complete clean dump, injected the Fsys area and did a CRC.
which didn't solved my issue but it was necessary.
Then I did a reflow with my Quick 861DW air station at 430 deg and 90 L per minutes air flow
The machine turns ON now, charges and displays OS loggon screen......

You can set the topic as solved.

As we know I will not trust this fix, as I could come back in after 2 days or 2 yeards who knows.......that remind me XBox 360 issues......

Thanks for your help

Best Regards
